Numerous countries are today using wind farms as a way to fully use what power can be generated by the wind. These farms are able to generate electricity in large amounts, when the wind turbines work together. Knowing how the wind farms work will demonstrate to you how efficient they might be. The blades are set on a shaft, and when the wind blows, it turns the blades and thus the shaft. The shaft is linked to a generator, which produces electricity from the turning action of the shaft. Employing the power intrinsic in the flow of water rather than wind, hydropower is made in the same way.

The power produced by one turbine is sufficient, at best, for no more than a farm, so bigger electrified areas require more than just one wind turbine. When there is a huge grouping of wind turbines, such as a wind farm, working unitedly, much electrical energy can be created. The electrical energy produced is enough for running a whole town when you store it on an existing utility grid or in special large-scale battery cells.
